text: Is there a way to remove srcset from an image, I am using hover effect in src, but as srcset automatically sets the hover effect is not visible.
you can remove using jquery
That’s far more simple than the check I had in mind lol - I was thinking dividing into the list size to get whole number loops then checking against that iterator

I created my own html/hubl template and I am trying to add a flexible column into it.
```
                    {% widget_container "PageContent" wrapping_html='', per_widget_wrapper_html='', overrideable=false, label='PageContent' %}
                    {% end_widget_container %}
```

but when I try and publish this template, I get error:

`Error:Missing "widget_container"`

If I remove the lines above from the template, it’s published
try making the name of the field all lowercase ( not talking about the label)
got the same issue
try it without the additional attributes e.g. `{% widget_container "page_content" %} {% end_widget_container %}`

changed to `{% widget_container "page_content" %} {% end_widget_container %}`

same result :disappointed:
weird. I’m not seeing anything else that looks incorrect
figured it out

when I created this template, I selected Html & Hubl template
then I selected “Blog” as the Template Type
i just created another one and selected “Page”
and it works
whats the difference between the two template types? can I just use the “Page” template for a blog?
I think flex columns just aren't supported on blog templates
flex columns are not supported in blog templates.

The difference between the two template types is that blog templates are meant to either be a post or listing view. The listing view does not have a UI for managing flex columns/modules therefore a flex column would be pointless. Blog Posts UI do not support adding/re-arranging modules in a flex column, this is likely an intentional choice to make the blog posts less cumbersome. it also takes away from the point of a blog. A blog is supposed to be a post. If you’re building out a full page that needs every aspect of it to be customizable you’re probably better suited using a page or landing page anyways
Or you can put all that content that you want control of in a HubDB table!
Well, was trying to manage the side-bar modules on the on the blog post or listing pages. Sometimes we might want a sign up in the side bar, or sometimes we might need something else.

another thing i found (and the better reason i’d rather use Page type) is that the blog based template forces use of the “hubtheme-style.css” file, and I’m not sure how to remove it. 

that file forces HubSpot’s styles and dropdowns on my header mega menu, thus breaking it/
my Page type  “Master” template includes public_common.css and layout.min.css which is preferable and gives me more freedom
Is there a way to not be forced to use “hubtheme-style.css” when creating a blog template?

You should just be able to remove that from the css dependencies for the template. If it's not in there, also make sure you've disabled domain stylesheets for the template, because it's probably set on the domain level
I pretty much always disable domain stylesheets on all my templates
Found that it was included in the domain settings for the blog — removed it and that fixed it it. Thanks!

Challenge for Ya'll :metal:
> Who can give me a 1-2 paragraph explanation of what HubL is, why you like it, and how it compares to PHP. 
> :boom:BONUS:boom: for including helpful links 

(working on "discovery kit" for new-to-HubSpot developers)

HubL is like PHP and Python Netflix’d and chilled. HubL is HubSpot’s custom version of the jinja templating language. While  the `{%` `%}` symbols are different from `<?php` and `?>` the languages are similar enough that you can probably read most HubL code if you have a basic understanding of PHP. and with the ability to echo variables just like:`{{ variable }}` you’ll wonder why you ever `<?php echo shouted ?>` in the first place.
"PHP and Python Netflix’d and chilled" :joy:
hahaha

Great overview Jon! - Thank you so much - I'm sure new-to-HubSpot developers will appreciate that. 

Who else has their own take - or - could add on to Jon's?

I added a new function to lookup the latitude/longitude of a post/zip code: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/en/docs/hubl/hubl-supported-functions#postal-location>. Please no more huge HubDB table imports with every US zip code mapped to a location :upside_down_face:
